entry.title: Combined summary - Should Graftroot be optional?
entry.summary: Bitcoin developers are discussing the implementation of Graftroot and Taproot, which offer different trade-offs for spending paths in transactions. While Graftroot is more compact when dealing with multiple spending paths, Taproot allows for proving all the different spending paths. There are concerns about accidentally signing scripts and the potential for certain participants to remove others from the set of signers in a multisignature setting without Graftroot. Developers are also discussing the possibility of introducing graftroot-like delegation to all existing and new P2PK and P2PKH UTXOs with a soft fork. In this design, SIGHASH_GRAFTROOT = 0x40 would be defined, and new rules would apply if (nHashType & SIGHASH_GRAFTROOT). The bitcoin developers believe there is no reason to make Graftroot optional, at the expense of block space and/or reduced privacy. In addition, Pieter Wuille has raised questions about whether a practical deployment needs a way to explicitly enable or disable the Graftroot spending path, while Gregory Maxwell has raised concerns about the possibility of funds being paid to a public key without any accountability. Overall, while there are concerns about the implementation of Graftroot, developers are continuing to discuss potential reasons why it could or could not be adopted in certain applications.On the Bitcoin-dev mailing list, Wuille discussed the potential need for an explicit enable or disable feature for the Graftroot spending path. This was in response to a concern that parties involved in signing a transaction could collude and break the original purpose of a particular P2SH address, potentially circumventing the rules set forth by the script. Additionally, there were concerns about the use of SIGHASH_NOINPUT and its impact on blind signature schemes. One proposed solution was to include a free "flags" byte in the witness, but some argue that it may not be necessary to include Graftroot in the Taproot proposal later. Another issue raised was the importance of preserving the "one signature = at most one input" rule for certain outputs. The discussions also covered the technical details of Graftroot, including its delegation capabilities and the potential for malleability issues. Overall, the discussions were focused on finding solutions to the challenges posed by these proposals while maintaining the security and integrity of the Bitcoin blockchain.Pieter Wuille, a Bitcoin Core contributor and blockchain expert, has raised concerns about the deployment of Taproot and Graftroot. He suggested that a practical deployment could require a way to explicitly enable or disable Graftroot spending. Wuille listed several approaches to this, but noted that all of them are less efficient or private than always permitting Graftroot spends directly. On May 24th, 2018, Gregory Maxwell raised concerns regarding the possibility of graftroot in Bitcoin transactions. He pointed out that if graftroot is possible, it would mean that funds were paid to a public key and the holder(s) of the corresponding private key could sign without constraint, thus there wouldn't be any accountability regardless of graftroot.The bitcoin-dev mailing list discussed the implications of Graftroot, a proposal to delegate control over a script to another party. One argument against making Graftroot optional was that delegation is not strictly less powerful than using a normal transaction since the signer could have signed an arbitrary transaction instead. However, Tim Ruffing disagreed and argued that Graftroot enables delegation in such a way that the delegation itself cannot be fixed in the chain, which is not currently possible.ZmnSCPxj proposes modifying the Taproot equation to make Graftroot optional and combining Taproot and Graftroot. He suggests using a one-level Merkle tree, where one branch enables or disables Graftroot and the other branch is an ordinary script. In a message on the Bitcoin development mailing list, Pieter Wuille asked whether practical deployment of Taproot and Graftroot would require explicit enablement or disablement of the Graftroot spending path. One reply to the message suggested that requiring a flag to allow the usage of these features in a transaction could be a good idea.Overall, the discussion on the bitcoin-dev mailing list revolves around Graftroot and whether it needs to be optional or not. The idea is that a script type could exist which looks like a pubkey Q, but can be spent either by key spending or by proving Q was derived as Q = P + H(P,S)*G, with a script S and its inputs (Taproot script spending), or by signing a script S using Q and providing S's inputs (Graftroot script spending). Both approaches have different trade-offs, with Graftroot being more compact when dealing with many spending paths while Taproot lets you prove all the different spending paths. The discussions also addressed the issue of making graftroot signatures independent of the outpoint, as this greatly reduces their functionality.
